title: Improving Customer Experience and Service Delivery for the American People
summary: Directs federal agencies to put people at the center of everything the Government does by improving the public's customer experience with Government services.
full_text: Directs federal agencies to put people at the center of everything the Government does by improving the public's customer experience with Government services.
plain_language_summary:
Improving Federal Customer Experience

Overview: President Biden directed federal agencies to put people first by improving the public's experience with government services. The order aims to make federal services more customer-centric.

Bottom Line: This order will not require significant action from most higher education institutions.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Federal Research Grants: Interactions with federal grant-making agencies may become more user-friendly over time.

Student Financial Aid: Processes for FAFSA and federal student loans could be streamlined.

University Hospital Systems: Interfaces with CMS, VA, and other agencies may be modernized.

Affected Departments:

Financial Aid Office, Research Administration, University Hospital Leadership

Action Plan:

Action Required: No. Aside from general awareness, no proactive steps are needed from most institutions at this time.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Review order and inform relevant offices listed above.

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Monitor any communications from affected federal agencies on planned service changes.

Long-term Considerations:

  • Consider user experience improvements in institution's own customer-facing services.

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: None

Budget: None

Technology: None

External Expertise: None
executive_brief:
Executive Brief

Biden orders agencies to improve customer experience with government services. Minimal direct impact on higher education.
comprehensive_analysis:
Executive Order on Improving Federal Customer Experience and Service Delivery

Overview: President Biden issued an executive order directing federal agencies to make government services more transparent, equitable, and responsive to public needs. The order requires agencies to modernize programs, reduce administrative burdens, and pilot new online tools and technologies that can provide a simple, seamless, and secure customer experience.

Bottom Line: While this order demonstrates a shift toward more customer-centric federal services, it does not contain any specific mandates for higher education institutions. Universities should stay informed of any implementing guidance or process changes from agencies they interface with.

Policy Context:

Policy Background:

This continues efforts from the Obama administration to improve citizen-facing government services, with a renewed emphasis on leveraging technology. It builds on recent CX initiatives like the 21st Century Integrated Digital Experience Act.

Legal Framework:

The order relies on existing statutory authority and mostly sets high-level strategic direction. Specific legal implications will depend on individual agency implementing actions.

Higher Education Context:

Colleges have also been working to improve student-centric services and user-friendly digital tools. This aligns with broader trends toward consumerization of higher education.

Key Impacts on Higher Education:

Financial Aid and Student Loans: Students may see more streamlined FAFSA processes, clearer communication, and improved online interfaces from the Department of Education.

Research Grant Administration: Faculty and staff may experience more user-friendly systems and less red tape when applying for and managing federal research grants from agencies like NSF, NIH, DoD, DOE, etc.

University Hospitals and Clinics: Medical centers may see modernized processes from CMS and VA related to reimbursement, reporting, and coordination of care.

Immigration and Study Abroad: International student services may see improved visa processes and communication from DHS, State Dept, and USCIS.

University Technology Transfer: Tech transfer offices may experience easier interactions with USPTO and Dept of Commerce.

Affected Departments:

Financial Aid Office, Bursar/Student Accounts, Registrar, Research Administration, Sponsored Projects Accounting, Technology Transfer Office, University Hospital Leadership, Government/Community Relations

Implementation Details:

Compliance Requirements:

N/A - Compliance impact minimal unless tied to specific federal funding streams.

Technical Analysis:

Unclear how quickly legacy agency IT systems can implement modern CX tools. Interoperability with university systems will be important.

Cross-Functional Impacts:

Implementation will span financial aid, registrar, billing, research admin, international programs, and government affairs. Requires cross-campus coordination.

Risk Analysis:

Low risk. Main issue would be investing in changes to university processes/systems that don't end up aligning with federal efforts.

Strategic Considerations:

Competitive Implications:

Minimal - Most impacts will apply sector-wide. But universities with more seamless federal interactions could gain in student/faculty experience.

Long-term Vision:

Sets federal agencies on a path to provide more customer-centric, equitable, digitally-enabled public services. A more user-friendly relationship with key agencies like ED and research sponsors would benefit higher education in the long run.

Advocacy Opportunities:

Universities can comment on agency proposals, participate in user testing where offered, and advocate for tools/standards that enable integration with campus systems.

Action Plan:

Action Required: No - While universities should monitor relevant agencies for process changes, the order itself does not require any mandatory action. Proactive steps are optional but may be strategically beneficial.

Immediate Steps (0-30 days):

  • Circulate a brief summary to leadership team and affected departments.
  • Designate POCs in each area to monitor agency communications.
  • Identify any pain points or bottlenecks in institution's interactions with federal agencies.
  • Review customer service aspects of university's own digital tools and student-facing services.

Short-term Actions (1-3 months):

  • Compile recommendations to streamline internal processes that interface with federal systems.
  • Provide feedback to sponsors if solicited on improving grant-related systems.
  • Evaluate adopting human-centered design principles into university's digital modernization efforts.

Long-term Considerations:

  • Re-envision how to provide seamless, equitable, user-friendly experience to students and university community.
  • Partner with associations like AAU, APLU, COGR to advocate for research university priorities in implementation.
  • Leverage lessons learned to inform state/local policy agenda on student success and public service delivery.

Resource Requirements:

Personnel: No dedicated FTEs needed but will require coordination across multiple administrative areas. May benefit from cross-functional working group.

Budget: No direct budget impact from the EO, but aligning university efforts could require new investments in digital services modernization.

Technology: Monitor emerging federal CX tools and standards - adopting aligned technologies could ease integration but beware investing ahead of firmly defined standards.

External Expertise: Consider engaging firm with service design expertise to help craft seamless student experience integrating relevant touchpoints with government services.
